headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jonathan, and I will be your conference facilitator today. Welcome to Chevron's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference call over to the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Chevron Corporation, Mr. John Watson. Please go ahead.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Chevron's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. On the today are Pat Yarrington, our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Mount, the General Manager of Investor Relations. We will refer to th
componenttext:
Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Chevron's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. On the today are Pat Yarrington, our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Mount, the General Manager of Investor Relations. We will refer to the slides that are available on Chevron's website. 
Before we get started, please be reminded that this presentation contains estimates, projections and other forward-looking statements. We ask that you review the cautionary statement on Slide 2. 
Turning to Slide 3, today, we announced a quarterly loss and annual results that were significantly below prior years. Pat will walk you through the financial details but prior to that, I would like to provide a few thoughts. In 2015, we delivered strong underlying operating results. We had one of our best years in personal safety, process safety and environmental performance. On most measures, we either matched 2014's record low or set new lows in 2015. The downstream business produced strong financial performance, underpinned by one of the best years ever in terms of facility utilization and reliability. In upstream, we grew production by 2%, within the guidance we provided a year ago. Additionally, we logged a 5-year reserve replacement ratio of 113%. Despite the strong operating results and oversupplied market led prices to fall to levels not seen since 2014. As expected, our financial results suffered. Across the corporation, we are responding to this low price environment. Our priorities remain completing projects under construction and reducing spend of both operating expense and capital to levels consistent with current conditions. We'll also continue to divest assets where we can obtain a good value. Our #1 financial priority is to maintain and grow the dividend. We have a strong balance sheet for precisely transition times like this. Pat will now take you through our financial results.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, John. I will be presenting 3 slides on our financial results. Additional earnings and production variance slides along with the tabulation of special items are available in the Appendix section of the presentation on our website. Turning n
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, John. I will be presenting 3 slides on our financial results. Additional earnings and production variance slides along with the tabulation of special items are available in the Appendix section of the presentation on our website. 
Turning now to Slide 4, an overview of our financial performance. The company's fourth quarter loss was $588 million or $0.31 per diluted share. Excluding foreign exchange, impairments and other special items, earnings for the quarter totaled $491 million or $0.26 per share. For the year, earnings were $4.6 billion or $5.6 billion, excluding special items and foreign exchange. Return on capital employed was 2.5%, and our debt ratio at year-end was approximately 20%. During the fourth quarter, we paid $2 billion in dividends, bringing our total for the year to $8 billion or $4.28 per share. 2015 was the 28th consecutive year of annual per share dividend increases. 
Turning to Slide 5. Cash generated from operations was $4.6 billion during the quarter and $19.5 billion for the full year. Fourth quarter cash flow declined because of lower commodity prices and lower downstream margins. Proceeds from asset sales for 2015 were $5.7 billion, bringing our 2-year total to more than $11 billion. Cash capital expenditures were $7.4 billion for the quarter and $29.5 billion for the full year. At year-end, our cash and cash equivalents totaled more than $11 billion. During 2015, we borrowed approximately $11 billion and at year-end, our net debt stood at $27 billion, resulting in a net debt ratio of approximately 15%. 
Slide 6 compares 2015 full year earnings with 2014. Earnings for 2015 were $4.6 billion or approximately $14.7 billion lower than the 2014 result. Special items such as asset impairment, project suspensions and other surcharges along with lower gains on asset sales reduced earnings between periods by $3.1 billion, while the change in foreign exchange impacts increased earnings by approximately $300 million. Upstream earnings, excluding special items and foreign exchange, decreased $14.6 billion between periods as lower realizations were only slightly offset by higher liftings, lower operating costs and other items. Downstream results excluding special items and foreign exchange increased by $2.3 billion, primarily due to higher margins. The variance in the other segments primarily reflect lower tax items. I'd like to now turn it back to John.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat. Turning to Slide 7. We are aggressively reducing investments and driving costs out of our business. During 2015, total spend was down approximately $9 billion or more than 12%. Capital outlays alone were down $6 billion. Part of this reductio
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat. Turning to Slide 7. We are aggressively reducing investments and driving costs out of our business. During 2015, total spend was down approximately $9 billion or more than 12%. Capital outlays alone were down $6 billion. Part of this reduction was long scheduled as in-progress major capital projects were completed and outlays ramp down. In addition, capital expenditure savings were achieved because of deliberate choices being made to reprioritize and replace investments and by challenging supply chain costs. Operating expenses also declined between years. The largest impact occurred in our upstream and corporate segments, reflecting purposeful initiative to rationalize headcount and boost workflow efficiencies. In upstream, declining costs and growing production led to a lower operating cost per barrel, which is expected to exceed 10% when the final results are reported in our 10-K. 
Looking to 2016, we expect to see additional spend reduction in the range of 13% to 18% as the full year run rate effects of many of the 2015 initiatives come to bear and incremental cost-saving projects are implemented. 
Turning to Slide 8. Our investment priorities remain consistent. We will fund investments to ensure safe, reliable operations, complete the projects already under construction, enable investment in high-return short-cycle opportunities and preserve options for viable long-cycle projects. 
In December, we announced the 2016 capital program of $26.6 billion, which was within the guidance range provided on our third quarter earnings call. Since then, market conditions have deteriorated, and we will be responsive. Flexibility in our capital programs allows discretionary spend with a likely outcome for 2016 being near the bottom of our guidance range. 
Looking beyond 2016, our flexibility will continue to increase, and we expect further reductions in our capital program. 
Turning to Slide 9. Divestitures are a normal part of our portfolio. We will divest assets that no longer have a strategic fit or do not compete for capital with our other investment alternatives. Our asset sales program has been successful as well-timed transactions capture good value and generated $11.5 billion in cash through the end of 2015. Over 2016 and '17, we are targeting another $5 billion to $10 billion in investments. Publicly known in-progress transactions include New Zealand and South Africa downstream businesses, the Hawaii refinery, upstream and pipeline assets in the Gulf of Mexico shelf and gas storage assets in Canada. Additional opportunities are being pursued and will be disclosed in due course when commercial sensitivities permit. In all cases, we will only sell assets where we can realize fair value. 
Turning to Slide 10. In 2015, we grew annual production by 2%. Ramp-ups at major capital projects, including Jack/St. Malo and Tubular Bells in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico and Bibiyana expansion in Bangladesh along with the shale and tight production growth of approximately 30%, contributed to increased volumes. Additionally, current prices benefited production through PSC and other entitlement effects. Offsetting to increase this was the effect of a shut-in of the Partition Zone production, the impact of asset sales and a base decline of less than 2%. For 2016, production guidance is a range is flat to 4% growth. The uncertainty is a reflection of market conditions, current activities and divestment. To clarify, production from the Partition Zone remain shut in. The exact timing of production restart is unknown and dependent on dispute resolutions between sovereign states. Contribution from major capital project start-ups and ramp-ups will be significant in 2016, and small movements in timing or the pace of ramp-ups can make a significant difference in annual production. Uncertainty and exact timing and precise composition of asset divestments will be another variable because we are value driven on all sales. 
Finally, current market conditions will create impacts related to PSC and other pricing-related entitlement effects. Additionally, low prices will restrict our overall spend levels, which in turn, will result in somewhat higher base decline rates. 
Turning to Slide 11. Our reserve replacement in 2015 was 107%. We saw significant adds in our shale and tight assets, which reflects strong well performance results and new geologic data in these place. Additional volumes were booked based upon development drilling results at Wheatstone. Strong base business performance resulted in positive reserve revisions including Tengiz, Thailand, Nigeria and the Gulf of Mexico. Commodity price impact benefited entitlement volumes for profit-sharing and the variable royalty contracts. Our 5-year reserve replacement ratio is 113%. 
Now let's talk about progress on our major capital projects starting with Gorgon. Turning to Slide 12, at Gorgon, system commissioning from Train 1 in in the final stages with key process units starting up, a cooldown cargo delivered and systems calling underway. The first LNG production is expected within the next few weeks with first cargo anticipated soon after that. We will be ramping up Train 1 in the months ahead. Gas for Train 1 startup will come from wells. These wells have been successfully flow tested, and initial performance indications look good. 
On Trains 2 and 3, all modules have been delivered to site, and construction is progressing. from Train 1 are being applied in key milestones have been achieved on schedule, with start-ups expected at approximately 6-month intervals after Train 1. 
Turning to Wheatstone on Slide 13. On the upstream portion of the project, hookup and commissioning of the offshore platform is progressing. The trunk line is ready for service, and final tie in work is ongoing. 6 of 9 wells are drilled and completed offering sufficient well capacity for the first train. At the plant site, the operations center and LNG loading jetty is complete and APAC Hydro testing is ongoing. As previously communicated, initial module fabrication in Malaysia was delayed. We were successful in mitigating further delays, and all modules required for Train 1 are now on site. Piping and cabling work is ongoing. The pace of this work will determine critical path towards first LNG, which is expected to be mid-year 2017. Train 2 modules are underway and on track. 
Turning to Slide 15. I've just run through the steps we've already taken to improve our financial results and to be responsive to current market conditions. on the elements we control, operating expenses, capital outlays and project execution, you can expect even more improvements in 2016. However, price remains a significant uncertainty. I'll come back to that in just a minute. What I would like to talk about is on a project that we have -- that are also contributing to our performance. If you look at the chart on Page 14, you'll see that we have significant progress on new projects. We have the Lianzi and Moho Nord, which came on in the fourth quarter; Chuandongbei, the first time for Chuandongbei to come online; and here in January of 2016, we're seeing progress on Angola LNG as recommissioning is underway. We expect introduce gas to the plant later this quarter and have first LNG cargo in the second quarter. Mafumeira Sul in Angola, Banff in Indonesia and in the North Sea are also progressing towards expected start-up later in the year. I mentioned that the price is a very significant uncertainty to us going forward. 
If you look at Slide 15, you'll see a chart that was put together by Wood Mac. This obviously represents a significant source of uncertainty in cash flows going forward. But consistent with many of you, we believe demand will continue to grow. The larger wildcard of uncertainty, if you will, is supply. Non-OPEC liquids production, which is shown on this chart, remain much more resilient in 2015 that most predicted. With a significant contraction in global investment cost by low prices, the world with the supplies drop off. Wood Mac shows that growing this year thereby pushing the oil market into better balance. Until that balance occurs, prices will continue to be constrained, and the financial damage to the energy sector seen in 2015 will continue. Relative to balance sheet strength and growing flexibility on our spend, Chevron will be advantage relative to the others in this industry as prices rebound. We are well positioned to benefit when the market does balance and prices begin to rise because of the leverage that we have and our growing production profile. That concludes our prepared remarks. We're now ready to take some questions. [Operator Instructions] We will do our best to get all of your questions answered. So Jonathan, please open up the lines.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The dividend coverage priority, obviously, is key and very clear. On the third quarter call, you build out a bridge to cover the dividend with free cash flow by 2017, which looked fairly reasonable on the $50 or so environment, and you highlight the flexi
componenttext: The dividend coverage priority, obviously, is key and very clear. On the third quarter call, you build out a bridge to cover the dividend with free cash flow by 2017, which looked fairly reasonable on the $50 or so environment, and you highlight the flexibility for 2016 in the slide. So, I guess, I was wondering as we're looking out into 2017 if we're sub-$50, how low can you realistically go with additional CapEx and OpEx cuts before you feel like you might need asset sales or the balance sheet to bridge the gap? Is there a level of CapEx that don't want to go below?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our flexibility continues to grow. And we're obviously working on that number very closely. The level of spend -- if we continue to see the kinds of prices that we're seeing now, the cost of goods and services will continue to decline. We've got the
componenttext: Well, our flexibility continues to grow. And we're obviously working on that number very closely. The level of spend -- if we continue to see the kinds of prices that we're seeing now, the cost of goods and services will continue to decline. We've got the impact of foreign exchange rates, et cetera. The biggest change between what we'll spend this year and next year is really the ramp-down from major capital projects. So for example, this year, we'll be spending about $6 billion on LNG projects around the world. Obviously, finishing Angola LNG and then as we wind down Gorgon and have little more spend on Wheatstone, we expect next year that spend will be under $2 billion. So you've gained $4 billion right there, and then our flexible the growth as time goes by. We all have to invest to keep our operations reliable. We will still have some projects that are under construction and being completed and additional commitments in drilling off of platforms and things of that sort. But I think our flexibility is significant. We gave you a range of $20 billion to $24 billion, but we're going to continue to drive that number down. I guess, my overall message is that we're going to continue to live within our means that we have, and that obviously makes sense to finish the projects under construction. We have a strong balance sheet. And maybe I'll offer a couple of comments in that area because a lot of people ask. I've given the priority as being in growing the dividend and in order to do that, obviously, you do have to invest in the business because we are a depleting resource business. So those are always the first 2 priorities that we have, consistent with good economics on spending. We've indicated that we're in a long-cycle business. And in such a long cycle business where you can have ups and downs in the commodity markets and you get started on long cycle projects, you need a strong balance sheet. And so we have always advertise that and indicated that a AA rating was what we were looking for. And that is what's really indicative of meeting to have a strong balance sheet. But the reason you keep a strong balance sheet is so you can withstand the ups and downs of the business. And right now, we're in the downs with prices low and so we'll use our balance sheet this year. Almost regardless of where prices are during the year. And we're going to cut costs. We're going to produce spend where we can, and that flexibility grows in time. We work very closely with the rating agencies. We talk to our rating agencies. They see our internal forecast around our business. They see more than you do, in other words, and so we'll be very clear where our priorities are, where the visibility is. And then they have to do their job. But we think that we will retain a very strong balance sheet and the ability to withstand the ups and downs.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And just on the projects, appreciate all the updates in there. Maybe just let us know where you stand on the FID for Tengiz and given what you've been saying about the macro environment and how long is that last, where does that
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And just on the projects, appreciate all the updates in there. Maybe just let us know where you stand on the FID for Tengiz and given what you've been saying about the macro environment and how long is that last, where does that stand today?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, Phil, it's a good question. Tengiz, as you know, has been a very good business for us in Kazakhstan. We and our partners have had very good relationship there, and we've had a lot of success financial and otherwise. The next phase of opportun
componenttext: As you know, Phil, it's a good question. Tengiz, as you know, has been a very good business for us in Kazakhstan. We and our partners have had very good relationship there, and we've had a lot of success financial and otherwise. The next phase of opportunity there as of the Wellhead Pressure Management Project and the future growth project. And we've been working this for some time, and we consciously delayed FID. When prices came down, we consciously delayed FID so that we could get additional definition around the project, a greater certainty around what the cost will be and frankly, to drive costs down given the opportunity that is present given the conditions and the industry. And we've had some success with that. But we're not at the point where we're ready to take FID today with low prices that we're seeing, we're working closely with our partners to each with that we have adequate funding for the project and to further take costs down. We have been facing investment. We've been doing critical infrastructure work. But we're still working this project to get it and condition for FID. So I think you see us continue to base investments and we'll keep you updated when we can. We do think these projects are good. We do think that they well go forward, but we're continuing to work it to drive costs down and get alignment on financing.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, 2 questions, if I may. For 2016, you gave a range of $25 million at the low end, and you indicate that you -- given the market conditions, you'll most likely go down to $25 million. If you really have to, is there any additional area that you would
componenttext: John, 2 questions, if I may. For 2016, you gave a range of $25 million at the low end, and you indicate that you -- given the market conditions, you'll most likely go down to $25 million. If you really have to, is there any additional area that you would be willing to cut and drive it down further? And what that area and by how much? Or that this is really the minimum that you can go, given the major project spending? The second question, if I could, is a quick one. We understand that you have one of the strongest partnerships, but the credit agency are also becoming increasingly hostile to the energy sector and look like that they may have a separate anyway. So what may be the minimum credit rating that is acceptable by the company?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, in terms of flexibility when it comes to capital program, we've given you that range for a good reason. As I indicated, we've got some committed spend that's likely to go forward regardless of the pricing environment. And really, it pertains t
componenttext: Okay. Well, in terms of flexibility when it comes to capital program, we've given you that range for a good reason. As I indicated, we've got some committed spend that's likely to go forward regardless of the pricing environment. And really, it pertains to the big LNG projects and the projects that are under construction. So we're going to continue to work spend down, and there's always a little bit more flexibility. There's the uncertainty of exchange rate and things of that nature, but I don't want to flag a significant reduction below the range, below the 26 6 million that's in our budget and below the range that we talked about. Because I don't want to shut in all rigs around the world, for example. There obviously are things that you could do, but I don't think of a proper thing to do given our expectations going forward. For example, we've done terrific work in the Permian Basin to get our costs down. And we want to keep that momentum going. So we have 6 operated rigs. There are 14 nonoperated rigs. We want to continue that activity. Our group has done a terrific job of getting cost down. And obviously, at $30, every business is stressed, but we think that supply is going to be needed, and we want to continue the activity that we have there and to continue to drive down cost that want to continue that activity. So there's a little bit more room, but I don't want to flag something outside that range. Maybe I'll let  -- I offer some comments on sort of the philosophy. Maybe I'll let Pat talk about interaction with the rating agencies and our view on what sort of minimum requirement might be.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as John said, the rating agencies need to do what the rating agencies need to do. And so they have a conservative oil price scenarios out there, and I think that's understandable. If you were in there position, you would be doing the same thing. A
componenttext: Yes. So as John said, the rating agencies need to do what the rating agencies need to do. And so they have a conservative oil price scenarios out there, and I think that's understandable. If you were in there position, you would be doing the same thing. And I think it's perfectly reasonable to think Chevron along with everybody in the industry in this particular price of environment would be up for review. They've indicated that many of the companies are up for review. I am certain that Chevron will be in that queue right after the first tiering go through. So if a downgrade does occur and, I think they've been moving in that direction, but if that were to occur, we would not be -- the only one that would happen to. I don't see it materially impacting our cost of funds or materially impacting our ability to secure financing. And in terms of the minimum, I guess, I don't think of it that way. We have a strong balance sheet even after were to be a downgrade. We have a very strong balance sheet, amongst the strongest in the industry. And we've already committed and said multiple times that we are going to get balanced. We will live within our cash flow. And I think that is the profile we put forward to the rating agencies.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just say you asked about flexibility in CapEx for '16. I don't want to suggest there is an additional flexibility for '17 and '18 because there is, particularly if lower prices persist. But we've given you a range that reflects what we think today ba
componenttext: I'll just say you asked about flexibility in CapEx for '16. I don't want to suggest there is an additional flexibility for '17 and '18 because there is, particularly if lower prices persist. But we've given you a range that reflects what we think today based on the forward look. Obviously, if conditions remain where they are today, we'll review those numbers just like we want all our other operating statistics.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Gammel from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Gammel from Jefferies.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about as you're reviewing potential capital expenditure reductions, how the deepwater program actually fits into this discussion? Because I know the string of successes in both exploration and appraisal that's occurring in the Deepwat
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about as you're reviewing potential capital expenditure reductions, how the deepwater program actually fits into this discussion? Because I know the string of successes in both exploration and appraisal that's occurring in the Deepwater right now, so how do you think about that drilling program? And then secondly, within the Deepwater, how do you see that competing over the medium term? Do you still see that as being within the cost curve based upon your own projections where oil prices could go?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, it's a great question. as one of the areas, looking at very closely and, I guess, if I can take just a second and to sort of the back of a little bit, if you look at the macro environment on where supply is going to come from to meet any deman
componenttext: Yes, Jason, it's a great question. as one of the areas, looking at very closely and, I guess, if I can take just a second and to sort of the back of a little bit, if you look at the macro environment on where supply is going to come from to meet any demand estimate that might be out there. The world's going to need deepwater oil. It's a significant resources over time, those barrels are going to be needed. Now right now, the cost in the deepwater haven't come down quite as fast as they have on sure. We obviously have seen some rig rate reductions, but in general, as we get to deeper and deeper water, some projects are challenged. We have mentioned last year in our Analyst Meeting that we thought it would take larger key accumulations to make some of these deepwater projects successful. So the process numbers are being worked, but you're going to the bigger key relations and larger hubs in order to justify the infrastructure and then tiebacks similarly will be somewhat higher prices. We have some special charges in the fourth quarter and $0.5 billion was right now is. And that's a project that we fought would go forward. First, we thought it might have the potential to be a hub and then we thought it might have the potential to be a tiebacks or can I won't say that, that project at have gone forward and that it would it be minimum thresholds depending upon your forward view of prices. But relative to our alternatives, we felt that for the foreseeable future, we got better places to put our money. And so we made a very difficult position to not go forward with that project. And so the clock was ticking where it's going to require $2 billion of investments over the next 3 years so we just felt that over the next few years, we are going to have a better place to put our money, notably the Permian. And so it's -- the art of choices being made. Now we have a good position. We've have been successful as anyone. And we have been successful in driving cost down. We've seen -- I mean, really unbelievable progress last year. We had a 30% reduction in days per 10,000 feet in '15 versus '14. So our experience in the Lower tertiary, in particular, we're getting better and better at understanding and driving cost down. We're encouraged by what we've got anchor. We've got some appraisal work that's undergoing there. We've got another potential hub development within a group of fields that we had put together with a couple of quarters and industry to trying to create a hub class development. But this is a work in progress for us to make sure we can have a resource cost balance to make these projects attractive to meet our thresholds. I'm comfortable we'll be able to do that. It's just that we were push with Mexican and Moccasin and you're seeing others make similar choices if it doesn't quite fit relative to the alternatives.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So I will just say for the full year, if you look at income statement, the special items that are characterized by the explosion expense will be about $1.1 billion. And if you look at the full year for DD&A of the income statement, the special items amount to about $3.5 billion.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're going to get to 17 different questions on the same theme. But just you talked about $20 billion to $24 billion of CapEx in '17 and '18 and I think last call, you mentioned sort of a slower rate of growth, 1% to 1.5%. Obviously, that rate of
componenttext: I think you're going to get to 17 different questions on the same theme. But just you talked about $20 billion to $24 billion of CapEx in '17 and '18 and I think last call, you mentioned sort of a slower rate of growth, 1% to 1.5%. Obviously, that rate of growth also will help project execution and hopefully, cost will come down. If you were to go down to a lower number of terminal sort of CapEx for a period, maybe just talk a bit about the growth implications beyond 2017. How would it affect the growth rate? And then I have a follow on.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I'll be able to answer that fully here. I will probably give you -- we'll give you a more complete answer when we get to March where we have a chance to read through it. But I wish is if you look at growth not just through '17 but through '18
componenttext: I'm not sure I'll be able to answer that fully here. I will probably give you -- we'll give you a more complete answer when we get to March where we have a chance to read through it. But I wish is if you look at growth not just through '17 but through '18, we feel pretty good about it and that's largely in front of the products we haven't quite in 2018, you'll have a full year of production obviously from our big LNG projects, which you won't have in '17. We also have other projects that remain under construction now that will come during that period, projects like key in Canada and Big Foot and others that will come on in that window. So we'll have continuing momentum from those projects, and we'll be ramping up our shale activity during that. It's notably in the Permian. So I think the profile will be attractive beyond 2017. Now ultimately, the cumulative effect of the reduction in capital, if they persist at a low level will be filled. But I think we'll have a little more resilient than people think. Now that sort of things being equal depending upon where prices are, depending upon positive and things of that sort, both in terms of what sort of spend do you need to sustain production and definitely, that will be a function of a lot of things, notably the cost environment that we see. I do think that our position in the Permian gives us a little bit of an advantage over others during this period because you've seen some of the numbers we've given you. Previously, we have the capability to ramp that up and mitigate some of the declines. So even if we see a slight increase in our base decline, which has been tracking at under 2%, even if that goes up a little bit, we should be able to substantially mitigate a lot of that through the productivity that we have in the shale. But we'll try to give you a little more -- a little longer term outlook our upcoming Meeting in March, if that's okay.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the follow-on is in the OpEx and SG&A part of that reduction of 13% [ph] to 18% from $61 billion down to a lower number. I mean obviously, the market helps give you some OpEx and then there's some structural changes that you've made some physical
componenttext: And then the follow-on is in the OpEx and SG&A part of that reduction of 13% [ph] to 18% from $61 billion down to a lower number. I mean obviously, the market helps give you some OpEx and then there's some structural changes that you've made some physical position. I mean, should we think there's another big structural shift that you can make to maybe even outpace the market in terms of OpEx and SG&A reduction, say, into 2017?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're working really hard, and we're pulling all levers. Obviously, there were costs of goods and services and our procurement group has had a very degree of success. I would say we've had more success in the U.S. than internationally, number one. A
componenttext: Well, we're working really hard, and we're pulling all levers. Obviously, there were costs of goods and services and our procurement group has had a very degree of success. I would say we've had more success in the U.S. than internationally, number one. And so we'll continue to drive that hard. That's just a function of contracts and the competitive environment overseas. So one, we'll be working that's very hard. We'll be working additional efficiencies. Just as an example, our -- we have -- we still have reorganizations in flight. So our employee count was down about 3,200 between the end of '14 to the end of '15. There are another 4,000 coming this year, and a lot of that work is ongoing right now. So we're being careful. We're pretty thoughtful about the way we do this sort of work to make sure that we keep the right people in our organization for the longer-term. But the reality is activity is likely to be lower, and we do have a number of projects that will be ramping down, and that we're going to work to be fair about how we do that so that we keep a lot of the great talent that we have that's been working around the world. But there's no question. We're looking at organizations and have a number of reorganizations in flight. Our desire is to keep moving that. But I would say on a dollar basis, when you're growing production and bringing on the asset, you have operating expense that you will incur. That's why we gave you the unit OpEx number. But we drove that one down. There's still some final allocations for what goes into the 10-K in the oil and gas disclosure but it's down over $2 a barrel. And I think that general trend, we're going to continue to drive that number down. Remember in our OpEx, 40% of our OpEx is downstream. And our downstream has record performance this year and, as you know, they've had restructuring underway for some time. And it's not that they're immune from some of the efforts we have to produce cost, but I don't think you'll see a structural shift in our downstream cost. The corporate center, we've obviously looked at a Mason significant changes. A lot of people left the payroll in December, and so those benefits will be found in the ongoing work that I described in the upstream. So my message is driving it hard. We're trying to be thoughtful to be keep the talent within for the long haul and organization.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Terreson from Evercore ISI Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Terreson from Evercore ISI Group.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get some clarity on 0% to 4% growth projection and the point that John made a few minutes ago about higher decline rates typically, is it reasonable to assume that we're going to have growth this year from United States, Africa and Australia a
componenttext: I wanted to get some clarity on 0% to 4% growth projection and the point that John made a few minutes ago about higher decline rates typically, is it reasonable to assume that we're going to have growth this year from United States, Africa and Australia and declines elsewhere, if that's the accurate way to think about it?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Africa, Australia and the United States, I think that is a pretty good way to look at it. We didn't look at it by project. But we do have, obviously, the shale and tight that's growing and ongoing ramp-up in the Deepwater. Obviously, the projects in Austr
componenttext: Africa, Australia and the United States, I think that is a pretty good way to look at it. We didn't look at it by project. But we do have, obviously, the shale and tight that's growing and ongoing ramp-up in the Deepwater. Obviously, the projects in Australia and in Angola and volume from Angola, from Angola LNG. So I think that's a pretty good characterization of it, yes.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also, John, on the neutral zone, there's been some more commentary on progress, and so my question is, is the progress real to your knowledge? And if so -- and if it is, is production progress is underway, what period of time could both fee
componenttext: Okay. And then also, John, on the neutral zone, there's been some more commentary on progress, and so my question is, is the progress real to your knowledge? And if so -- and if it is, is production progress is underway, what period of time could both feel to return to full production if, in fact, there was movement? Meaning, is this something we should think about in terms of weeks or months or quarters? So just an update there would be appreciated.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I missed the first part of it.
componenttext: Sorry, I missed the first part of it.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the Partition Zone. Well, look, I give you guys a long explanation last quarter. The fields, they're still shut in, and there've been ongoing dialogue between Saudi's and the Kuwaitis. And as I described before, there's plenty of incentive to brin
componenttext: Yes, on the Partition Zone. Well, look, I give you guys a long explanation last quarter. The fields, they're still shut in, and there've been ongoing dialogue between Saudi's and the Kuwaitis. And as I described before, there's plenty of incentive to bring those fields back online. And I probably have to leave it there. What I'll tell you implicit in our assumption is about a mid-year startup. That's sort of -- the middle of that range includes a mid-year startup. But remember, 2014 production was about 80,000 barrels a day. When you start up mid-year, you don't start up at 80,000. You start at something lower than that because the facilities have been mothballed and preserved for a period of time. So that's what reflected. To the extent that, that agreement is reached and there have been discussions to the extent agreement is reached the departed up sooner, it'll be to the higher end of that range and to the extent that it continues, the bottom of the range is 0. If they don't start up at all this year.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I know I've kind of tried this one before, but in light of the further collapse in oil prices, I wanted to ask again about growth versus growth per share. What's really behind my question is further investing in a highly uncertain environment guessi
componenttext: John, I know I've kind of tried this one before, but in light of the further collapse in oil prices, I wanted to ask again about growth versus growth per share. What's really behind my question is further investing in a highly uncertain environment guessing or potentially subeconomic assets. Is it an argument just for deferred deferral an outright declines that can be picked up again through share buybacks if indeed what price that recover absent any major capital commitments? I'm just wondering philosophically how you think about, given the potential risk to your credit rating that we stand right now.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, actually, I think it's a fair question. I mean the message I've been trying to convey is that we are dramatically cutting investment going forward. We all have to make estimates of what oil and gas prices will be going forward. But in terms of longe
componenttext: Doug, actually, I think it's a fair question. I mean the message I've been trying to convey is that we are dramatically cutting investment going forward. We all have to make estimates of what oil and gas prices will be going forward. But in terms of longer cycle projects, we are initiating -- we are initiating any. We've got -- as I described, we got the momentum in the system from project under construction, but we are -- you are going to see us preferentially favor short-cycle investments. And if they don't meet our hurdle, we won't invest. We're not -- they are -- taken to the extreme, we're not just going to invest to hold volume. We're going to invest where we think we can get good returns. And so we repurchased shares in the past and we'll do that again. We will fund opportunities that we don't be effective for the company. And you and I both put some hindsight that some of the things that we and others in the industry have put money in right now, but we're tightly scrutinizing what we're spending right now. And I hope I can make that really clear to you. I mean, that's indicative of the kind of choices we made with the Buckskin Moccasin. It's indicative of the kind of changes we made with a big development in the North Sea. It's -- that's the direction that work going, again trying to balance our expectations for the forward year.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the answer is, John. I'm sure it's not fun for anyone right now. But my follow-up is really nobody wants to take this, but it's only asset sales, there seems to be everybody moving to sell assets in right now. I'm just wondering if you can't
componenttext: I appreciate the answer is, John. I'm sure it's not fun for anyone right now. But my follow-up is really nobody wants to take this, but it's only asset sales, there seems to be everybody moving to sell assets in right now. I'm just wondering if you can't to maximize how you see the depth of the market and whether or not you think you can still execute on that program. And I'll leave it there.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a really good question. In fact, I think your point is spot on. I think, it's a terrible market to be trying to sell most assets out there, particularly, obviously on related assets. And that's what I've been pretty circumspect around asset sa
componenttext: Yes, that's a really good question. In fact, I think your point is spot on. I think, it's a terrible market to be trying to sell most assets out there, particularly, obviously on related assets. And that's what I've been pretty circumspect around asset sales. We sold $11 billion over the last 2 years, but we're giving you a $5 billion to $10 billion for the next 2 years in the numbers that I've given you. From a strategic point of view, there are some opportunities out there that will be tough to execute. And if we can't execute them, we won't sell them. If you look at the kinds of things we have sold, we've gotten very good value. So for example, the last 2 years, there was a lot of strength in infrastructure market, selling pipelines for example. And on strategy grounds, valuation grounds, we felt that we were going to limit our investment in the pipeline business to those that are critical to upstream and downstream sector and we can sell those, things like Caltex Australia. We thought values were very strong and assets -- we've been very well-aligned with them, but that they were heading off potential to be the growth direction, and we felt that from our strategic point of view that it might be best exit when we did. So we've been very careful, and I can tell you the assets going forward, we don't advertise them but you look at the ones where there's information in the public domain, I think you'll see that those assets where there are potential buyers out there at good value. So I think your admonition is a very good one, and it's why we haven't put the numbers out there.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you mentioned the Tengiz question before. Are there any other FIDs that are quickly baked into 2016 and your 2017 to '18 budget ranges? And I guess, as it relates to CapEx, I mean how much visibility is fair to open for reprice contracts within proj
componenttext: John, you mentioned the Tengiz question before. Are there any other FIDs that are quickly baked into 2016 and your 2017 to '18 budget ranges? And I guess, as it relates to CapEx, I mean how much visibility is fair to open for reprice contracts within projects post-FID? It appears to be there's more flexibility at least than we have perceived.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. Obviously, for any project we have in flight, we went back to all the project teams and create expectation that they will tried to capture cost reductions. And in some cases where you have -- where you big contracts and terms an
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. Obviously, for any project we have in flight, we went back to all the project teams and create expectation that they will tried to capture cost reductions. And in some cases where you have -- where you big contracts and terms and conditions are fixed, you are where you are. But I mean anything we haven't taken out FID, you have some flexibility to go back to the providers of those services. And that's why we delayed our costs. I mean part of their we cycle of projects is to see if there's a different development scheme and things like that. For example, Rosebank has a different develop and scheme. But to part of it is also the major that we can capture the cost reductions that are available -- that might be available in the marketplace. And sometimes, you have to just say we're not going to do that if we don't get better cost and that tends to focus partners and others. And so we expect that the declining break even as a result of those initiatives both the reframe project in some cases or to try to drive costs out. In terms of what we've got actually plant, most of the effort -- most of the things that we would call FIDs, I really think like infield drilling so for example, the next phase of drilling at the next stage of drilling in Jack/St. Malo, which are utilizing existing rigs and drilling off of existing -- to support existing infrastructure. In terms of big, new greenfield projects, it's relatively few. There are some that could be in the budget, but it's going to depend on that price cost balance I've been talking about. And that's why I say we have significant flexibility going forward as we complete things like Gorgon, Wheatstone, Mafumeira Sul, Angola LNG and others.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like they're not currently in the budget. Just sort of a follow-up question or just a smaller I can. Our at the start of volumes at Gorgon, are they spot or contract pricing? And can you give us any color or update on the spot energy market a
componenttext: So it sounds like they're not currently in the budget. Just sort of a follow-up question or just a smaller I can. Our at the start of volumes at Gorgon, are they spot or contract pricing? And can you give us any color or update on the spot energy market and whether you see an ability to firm up an incremental under contract at Gorgon volumes? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in general, the sales will be under contract. We've -- In fact, you've seen quite recently we have signed a couple of additional HOAs. We said all along that we thought it appropriate to have that 85% under long-term contract for Gorgon and Wheatston
componenttext: Yes, in general, the sales will be under contract. We've -- In fact, you've seen quite recently we have signed a couple of additional HOAs. We said all along that we thought it appropriate to have that 85% under long-term contract for Gorgon and Wheatstone. And with those HOAs, assuming those turn into SPAs, we'll be over 80%. So we feel pretty good about that. Those are medium-term type contracts that we put in place. So we feel good about that. But during the wrapup, we've got contracts that are available for these volumes. Now as far as the overall LNG market, it's lousy. When you look at the spot cargoes and prices, and I expect we're going to go through a challenging the industry. We're going to go through a challenging period for any of volumes that will be sold spot into the marketplace.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question. maybe you've talked kind of indirectly a bit about your view towards the short cycle on the onshore in the near term, and I appreciate some of that color. But can you talk about trends and activity levels of volumes, particularly in the Permia
componenttext: A question. maybe you've talked kind of indirectly a bit about your view towards the short cycle on the onshore in the near term, and I appreciate some of that color. But can you talk about trends and activity levels of volumes, particularly in the Permian? I think just in the broader sense, and how do you look to manage the short-cycle spend during the near to medium term? I mean it sounds like it's clearly taking preference over long-cycle spend. But what's dictating the difference between spending $3 billion or $2 billion or $1.5 billion? So how do you manage that over the medium term?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a fair question. I mean, the short answer is there's some judgment that we're applying. We have been on a pathway in the Permian of first assessing what we have. So we've been drilling both vertical and horizontal wells. Over the last year, we'v
componenttext: Yes, it's a fair question. I mean, the short answer is there's some judgment that we're applying. We have been on a pathway in the Permian of first assessing what we have. So we've been drilling both vertical and horizontal wells. Over the last year, we've really converted our entire program to horizontal wells and really getting -- an overused term, getting our factory model in place, and we've done that. And our costs are now very competitive with some of the best in the business. So that is taking place, and we want to continue that effort. Our view is not that prices are going to stay at the low range they are today. But part of living within your means is limiting just how many rigs you deploy. We've got 6 operated rigs today. We've got 14 or JV brands that are operating today. We think that's about the right balance. We have flexibility to move up. And what I've told our people, if they stay on the cost trajectory that they are, we're going to look to fund them. The economics and some of the best areas extra type prices work, but the discuss with higher prices but they work. And so that obviously is guiding us. But I would hate to lose the momentum that we have in the Permian with some of the cost reduction efforts we have underway. And we've told you, we've got 3,000 locations that we think are lean economic threshold at $50. So ultimately, prices aren't $50 a day, but it's indicative of the strength of the portfolio that we have.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, I appreciate that. And maybe just one kind of step-back question, and we spent a lot of time these days talking about how rough everything is and all the costs that are having a hiccup. But maybe if you took around adjust look at the other side, ca
componenttext: Great, I appreciate that. And maybe just one kind of step-back question, and we spent a lot of time these days talking about how rough everything is and all the costs that are having a hiccup. But maybe if you took around adjust look at the other side, can you and opportunities that you're seeing? I mean, the cost structure is clearly 1 but anything you're seeing emerge as you look to positioning your business for the next cycle, some of the positive things whether it's a resource capture, fiscal terms or any other opportunities that are kind of silver lining than what we're seeing right now?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for silver lining question, Ryan. We're looking for those internally, too. You're right, it is very tough times. The couple of thoughts that I'll give you. One, I think the cost reduction but we're going after, most of them will be permanent. Fo
componenttext: Thank you for silver lining question, Ryan. We're looking for those internally, too. You're right, it is very tough times. The couple of thoughts that I'll give you. One, I think the cost reduction but we're going after, most of them will be permanent. For example, the efficiency that we've guided our drilling, those are permanent regardless of what happens to rig rates going forward to what it is a Deepwater that I talked about earlier for not. So that's number one. Number two, I think the benefits that we're taking on at some of our organization to some of our structures, I think a lot of that will be permanent. And I think we've undervalued what simplicity org structures can provide. So obviously, we think announced some players. We've got rolling with organizations that are being implemented around the world, and I think that diversity and clarity will be a positive for the business. In terms of resource capture, there are better opportunities today than there might have been a year ago. And the balance between what I'll say the expectations and a value of resource is getting better aligned. So there are opportunities emerging. I meet our priority, is obviously things I talked about this morning. But we are in a resource business, and you do want to be attentive to the opportunities that are out there.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neil Mehta of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you made the comment that non-OPEC supply has been relatively resilient over the course of the year. You also made the point that the base decline rates was less than 2% in your portfolio over the course of this year. How does that compare relative
componenttext: John, you made the comment that non-OPEC supply has been relatively resilient over the course of the year. You also made the point that the base decline rates was less than 2% in your portfolio over the course of this year. How does that compare relative to history? And if you look at 2016, how do you think your base decline rate looks like towards the midpoint of guidance?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In general, I mean the 2 are somewhat related. Our base today has been cut because we operated very reliably, and it's gotten quite efficient in our business. And so we have been able to mitigate the declines. We've also flagged those with a lower level o
componenttext: In general, I mean the 2 are somewhat related. Our base today has been cut because we operated very reliably, and it's gotten quite efficient in our business. And so we have been able to mitigate the declines. We've also flagged those with a lower level of spending and base business, infield drilling in places like Bakers Field and elsewhere, you are going to see declined slightly higher. So that's why we suggest that, and we do expect to see that across the industry. The history has shown given downturns like this, you can see an increase of a percent or 2 industry-wide in that base decline. So that is -- I think that's clear. In terms of the resiliency that we've seen in production, it's partly related to that, but to me, it's been -- if you look at 2015, the impact of projects that were in flight has probably been more than we as an industry anticipated. So we're not the only ones with Jack/St. Malos and Bibiyanas and other projects that are under construction better that are coming up. Second of course, you've had the impact of hedges and the unconventional business and the brief update that took place in the middle of 2015 in prices did allow additional hedges. So you've still got a few hedges that are out there in the industry in 2016 that will allow some level of activity. But increasingly, all that's wearing off as the projects come online, as base business declined start to take over and as hedges are no longer available. And so I think that's why you're seeing those volumes. The other piece that I've consistently said has been underrepresented is the stress around the world, the stress on governments, the stress on those government partners, national oil companies and others. And you've seen announcements that have been made because while we tend to think of living within our means as a function of forward capital spend, for host governments living within their means, it's social. It's a choice between social spending and reinvesting in the business. And you've seen some of those choices play out in the guidance that has been given by host governments to national oil companies in certain countries. And so I think all the cumulative weight of all this action will tend to bring things in balance. And you still have potential sources of supply out there. Obviously, Iran is bringin volumes on, but I think the trend is inexorable.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you've part answered this question. My original question was going back to the volumes. It looks like quite a big percentage range but in barrels a day, it's only about 100,000 barrels a day for 2016. That's to say 0% to 4% range of uncertainty. You
componenttext: John, you've part answered this question. My original question was going back to the volumes. It looks like quite a big percentage range but in barrels a day, it's only about 100,000 barrels a day for 2016. That's to say 0% to 4% range of uncertainty. You part answered the question because you addressed the Partition neutral Zone. Can you talk a bit about that the variances in the other elements? So how much of volume potentially variances there and the start-ups, the divestments, the price effects and the spend levels? Because it feels like that 100,000 barrels is actually not that wide. It picket seems bigger percentage but not so much volumes.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a very good observation. The range is wide and you've got multiple moving parts in the business. Let me see if I can give you a little bit of color. Just if you look at the dividends of $30 and $60 per barrel just on price effects, it can be o
componenttext: Yes, that's a very good observation. The range is wide and you've got multiple moving parts in the business. Let me see if I can give you a little bit of color. Just if you look at the dividends of $30 and $60 per barrel just on price effects, it can be over 100,000 barrels a day for that alone. And so you're right, there is a range there. And what happens in a place like Indonesia, for example, for a given level of spend and you have cost barrel reimbursement, the lower the price, the more barrels you get. And these curves are all linear in different locations around the world. And so there is considerable variability from price alone. If you think about ramp-up of production, I'll give you an example on Gorgon. Gorgon, the 3 trains in Gorgon, our share is a little over 200,000 barrels a day. So if you think about each train is 65,000 to 70,000 barrels a day. And we said we expect production within to commence within a few weeks. There's an industry curve. The industry average is around ramp-up schedule that takes place over a period of months. And to the extent at the high end of that range really have a small start-up. We have the well capacity. So you could have a very rapid ramp-up. Our people in Australia don't know what they don't know, and so we have taken more of an average approach. And to the extent you count is something unusual, you can be on the downside of that. Our people in Angola LNG at this point are pretty gun shy because we've had challenges, but that's 60,000 barrels a day. And we said that we expect to be introducing gas later this quarter, and to have cargoes the second quarter. But there's variability around that and the ramp-up, and so all of those -- and by the way, there's a second train in Gorgon as well later this year. So all of those can impact the pace of development. And then, I guess, just the outright spend that's a function of rigs and activity. I think it's fair to say that if we keep seeing prices in the low 30s, we're going to drop rigs as the principals on. And then that last piece is one that I will provide much specifics is really divestments because we've indicated for example that our shallow water and activity that we have packages for shale out there, and those have some volumes attached to them. I mean there's some other potential assets in the upstream under consideration, but it really depends on getting the value and timing of those. And so that is why you get a range of you are correct. The range can be broader than indicated there, but that I felt if I give you any broader range, you'd say this is wasn't very helpful.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alastair Syme from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alastair Syme from Citi.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, can you just come back to your comment on the divestment market? You said it's a terrible market for selling assets, therefore, you appreciate the balance sheet constrains but what leads you away from temptation?
componenttext: John, can you just come back to your comment on the divestment market? You said it's a terrible market for selling assets, therefore, you appreciate the balance sheet constrains but what leads you away from temptation?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: What leads me away from the temptation? Well,, I know you've heard over the years but if I just the ground everyone on the phone, what we said over many years is that we're in the resource business. It's declining and we will replace resource through a co
componenttext: What leads me away from the temptation? Well,, I know you've heard over the years but if I just the ground everyone on the phone, what we said over many years is that we're in the resource business. It's declining and we will replace resource through a combination of exploration, discovered resources, participation and acquisitions. And so Chevron has done that over time. Our goal in position has been and so M&A hasn't been a particular priority for us. But we are mindful of the opportunities that are out there. -- I wouldn't want to thank our focus is anything other than getting the projects we have under construction and completing the work we have and ramping up efforts that we have because I think we got a pretty nice business profile going forward. But we do need to look at what is out there and we're going to be value-driven, but there are opportunities that could the present themselves in the current market. So we'll be mindful of that. But remember, we're trying to grow the business and invest for the long term here. And, so we're not driven -- we're not particularly transaction driven in any period of time. I have time for one more question.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: A quick one on shale if I may and tight oil. headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the increase of that 44, about 2/3 of it was Permian Wolfcamp, and the rest of it was between Argentina and some of our Appalachia activity. And in terms of what's forward-looking, I think I'm going to leave that to the Security Analyst Meeting that
componenttext: Yes, the increase of that 44, about 2/3 of it was Permian Wolfcamp, and the rest of it was between Argentina and some of our Appalachia activity. And in terms of what's forward-looking, I think I'm going to leave that to the Security Analyst Meeting that we've got coming up in March where we give you a little deeper insight into our work in the Permian and kind of the range of ramp up that we could see there. And we've done that every year, and we'll update you this year based on both the cost improvements that we've seen and the realities of the price market that we're in. Okay.

componenttext: Answer the second question first, no. We're not able to do that. So we don't. I would just say that we've got our hands a pretty small. Some have speculated that it's going to be a little harder than advertised. But I don't have any particular insight to offer you. And perhaps others can help you with that. Okay. I would like to thank all of you for being on the call today. We appreciate your interest in our company and your participation. We look forward to seeing you at our March Meeting in New York. Thank you.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
