headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jonathan, and I will be your conference facilitator today. Welcome to Chevron's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now turn the confe
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jonathan, and I will be your conference facilitator today. Welcome to Chevron's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now turn the conference over to the Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Chevron Corporation, Ms. Pat Yarrington. Please go ahead.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Chevron's first quarter earnings conference call and webcast. On the call with me today are Joe Geagea, Executive Vice President of Technology, Projects and Services. Many of you know Joe, but for those of you wh
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Jonathan. Welcome to Chevron's first quarter earnings conference call and webcast. On the call with me today are Joe Geagea, Executive Vice President of Technology, Projects and Services. Many of you know Joe, but for those of you who don't, I thought it would be useful to highlight that he leads our technology, procurement and project functions. He also oversees our Centers of Excellence for upstream, including drilling. Also joining me on the call is Frank Mount, General Manager of Investor Relations. We will refer to slides that are available on Chevron's website.
Before we get started, please be reminded that this presentation contains estimates, projections and other forward-looking statements. We ask that you review the cautionary statement on Slide 2.
I'll begin with key messages from our March 2016 Security Analyst Meeting, followed by a recap of our first quarter 2016 financial results. Joe will provide some color around our spend reduction initiatives and discuss recent updates on key projects, prior to my concluding remarks.
Turning now to Slide 3. Our Analyst Day was about 7 weeks ago now, and I thought it would be worthwhile to reiterate the primary messages from that series of sessions. Preserving and growing the dividend is our first priority. Our intention is to be able to cover the dividend in 2017. Our capital spend profile is coming down. We are completing major capital projects already under construction but otherwise reducing long-cycle spend. We are lowering our cost structure to better match a low price environment by improving efficiencies, streamlining the organization and working with suppliers to achieve cost reductions.
At the same time, we expect our cash inflows to be growing. Production increases will occur as we bring on and ramp up projects. While volume growth is sensitive to any number of unknowns such as prices, divestments, ramp-up profile, we anticipate volume growth through the end of the decade using reasonable estimates for these and other uncertainties.
The cash generation of the new assets coming online is substantial to the point where these production adds are expected to raise the overall cash margin per barrel of the entire portfolio even absent any increase in price.
This year, we plan to use some of our borrowing capacity to complete projects. We have one of the strongest balance sheets in the industry, and we believe we can come through the lows of this price cycle with long-term financial strength intact. Our investment will shift to a higher proportion of short-cycle projects. Not only are many of these brownfield opportunities, but they will give us greater capital flexibility going forward to help limit further debt increases. 
Finally, we are focused on improving financial returns, reducing pre-productive capital, moving towards more short-cycle higher-return investments, lowering our cost structure and improving execution on major capital projects.
Turning to Slide 4, an overview of our financial performance. The company's first quarter loss was $725 million or negative $0.39 per diluted share. Excluding foreign exchange and special items, as detailed in an appendix slide, the loss for the quarter totaled $211 million or a negative $0.11 per share. Cash from operations for the quarter was $1.1 billion, and our debt ratio at quarter end was 22%. Our net debt ratio was 18%.
During the first quarter, we paid $2 billion in dividends. Earlier in the week, we announced the dividend of $1.07 per share payable to stockholders of record as of May 19. We currently yield 4.2%.
Turning to Slide 5. Cash generated from operations was $1.1 billion during the first quarter. Obviously, upstream cash generation has been heavily penalized by low commodity prices. Downstream continues to generate strong cash flow, although seasonal patterns are evident. 
During the quarter, operating cash flow reflected about $1 billion of working capital requirements as well as certain pension contributions. In addition, affiliate dividends were modest in the quarter, a pattern that is clearly price-related as we expect cash generation to improve going forward, as our costs come down and as prices move up. 
Cash capital expenditures were $5.6 billion, a decrease of approximately 27% from first quarter 2015. At quarter end, our cash and cash equivalents totaled approximately $8.9 billion, and our net debt position was about $33 billion.
Turning to Slide 6. Slide 6 compares current quarter earnings with the same period last year. First quarter 2016 results were $3.3 billion lower than first quarter 2015 results. About half of this quarter-on-quarter decline was in special items and foreign exchange. Overall, special items accounted for a negative variance between quarters of $755 million, the bulk of which related to last year's recognition of both asset sale gain and the favorable impact of changes in U.K. petroleum tax regulation.
A swing in foreign exchange impacts decreased earnings by $900 million between periods. As a reminder, most of our foreign exchange impacts stem from balance sheet translations and do not generally affect the cash.
Excluding special items and foreign exchange, upstream earnings decreased approximately $1.6 billion between quarters. Lower crud realizations were partially offset by higher sales volume and lower operating and exploration expenses. The realization change was in line with our sensitivity of $350 million per dollar change in Brent.
Downstream results, excluding special items and foreign exchange, decreased by approximately $475 million, primarily driven by lower worldwide refining margin. The variance in the other segment was primarily from lower corporate tax items. 
Turning to Slide 7. I'll now compare results for first quarter 2016 with the fourth quarter 2015. First quarter results were $137 million lower than fourth quarter. A swing in special items, mainly the absence of fourth quarter's impairment and project suspension charges, increased earnings by $930 million. Foreign exchange impacts went the other way, decreasing earnings by $365 million between periods. Upstream results, excluding special items and foreign exchange, decreased by approximately $750 million between quarters, primarily reflecting lower realizations, again in line with our sensitivity.
Downstream earnings, excluding special items and foreign exchange, were lower by $163 million. Weaker refining margins were partially offset by stronger trading results, lower operating expenses and the absence of year-end inventory charges from a draw into higher cost to prior year layers.
The variance in the other segment largely reflects lower corporate charges.
Slide 8 compares the change in Chevron's worldwide net oil equivalent production between the first quarter of 2016 and the fourth quarter of 2015. Net production decreased by 7,000 barrels per day between quarters. Major capital project ramp-ups, primarily at Gorgon and Australia, Chuandongbei in China and Lianzi in in West Africa, increased production by 11,000 barrels per day. The absence of planned and unplanned downtime, mainly at Tengiz and Kazakhstan, increased production by 25,000 barrels per day between periods. Shale and tight production declined 5,000 barrels a day between quarters as external constraints such as weather impact and downtime at a third party processing facility impacted the Permian. Price and cost recovery effects associated with production sharing and variable royalty contracts decreased production by 18,000 barrels per day between quarters as lower crude prices were more than offset by the impact from lower spend on cost recovery.
The remaining variance in the base business and other primarily reflects natural field declines and other adjustments. All this said, first quarter volumes are up about 2% from full year 2015 production. This is right in the middle of the guidance range we provided in January and reaffirmed in March. We still believe this guidance is appropriate.
Slide 9 compares the change in Chevron's worldwide net oil-equivalent production between the first quarter of 2016 and the first quarter of 2015. Net production decreased by 15,000 barrels per day between quarters. Major capital projects increased production by 38,000 barrels per day, primarily due to production ramp-ups from the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico, Bangladesh and West Africa, in addition to start-ups at Gorgon and Australia and Chuandongbei in China. Shale and tight production increased by 37,000 barrels per day due to the growth in the Permian and Marcellus in the U.S. and the Llarden Duvernay basins in Canada. 
Volumes associated with production sharing and variable royalty contracts increased production by 16,000 barrels per day as the positive impacts from lower crude prices was partially offset by the impacts of lower spending on cost recovery.
The shut-in of operations in the Partitioned Zone decreased production by approximately 76,000 barrels per day. The decrease of 30,000 barrels per day in the base business and other bar, primarily reflects normal field declines and the higher downtime activity, partially offset by production from new wells and favorable impact from reduced external constraints.
Turning now to Slide 10. We are making good progress at reducing our spend. These charts use a rolling fourth quarter average to illustrate capital and operating expense reductions. When comparing the rolling fourth quarter average of first quarter 2016 to the same period of the prior year, capital outlays are down 19%. In December, we announced the C&E program of $26.6 billion for the year. But as we noted in March, we are now targeting closer to $25 billion for the year. As we continue to finish major capital projects under construction, we will move to an absolute lower level of annual spend in future years as evidenced by our $17 billion to $22 billion range that we've given you for 2017 to 2018. Affordability considerations at the time will be paramount in determining actual budgets. Capital intensity will be going down. Capital discipline will be going up, using the same general pattern on operating expense, same downward pattern on operating expense. Expenses continue to rise through 2014 but then notably turn south in mid-2015 as our deliberate cost savings initiatives began to take hold. The rolling first quarter 2016 average is 6% lower than the comparable figure a year ago.
There are some transitional costs such as severance and rig termination fees that are incurred as we take steps to compete more effectively in the lower price environment. Once we're through with the transition cost and as we carry on with the implementation of our various cost savings initiatives, we expect to see continued movement towards the lower sustainable cost structure. Cost reduction momentum should continue through 2016 and 2017 as the full run rate of our actions is recognized.
Joe will now walk you through some specific examples of our cost reduction efforts before offering an update on key projects.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat. Turning to Slide 11, I'll start by providing some examples and supported paths analysis. Our efforts are focused on achieving sustainable reductions and improving efficiencies. On the organizational side, to date, we have reduced our emplo
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat. Turning to Slide 11, I'll start by providing some examples and supported paths analysis. Our efforts are focused on achieving sustainable reductions and improving efficiencies. On the organizational side, to date, we have reduced our employee headcount by more than 4,000 relative to year-end 2014, and we are on target to achieve approximately 8,000 total employee reductions by the end of 2016. We're also on target to reduce our contracted workforce by about 6,500 from 2014 levels. 
At the analyst meeting, we shared with you examples of how -- of our improved drilling efficiencies in the Permian and Gulf of Mexico. So today, let me give you an additional example from the different regions in the world. In Thailand, operational discipline and streamlined processes have enhanced drilling execution efficiency, resulting in about 45% lower average days per 10,000 feet yield in a 2-year period, as you can see in the graph. And we are continuing to outperform our regional competitors. We're also focused on improving our efficiencies in logistics. One example in West Africa includes shifting from [indiscernible] dedicated vessels to a centrally managed fleet using a decision support center. As a result of this effort, we expect to achieve savings of 30% and reduce the number of vessels in that region by about 40%. We're also continuing to take advantage of our size and scale. In a different part of the world, we are coordinating contract awards with 1 supplier across 3 different regions and reducing the number of vessels by optimizing marine vessel size.
One of our focus areas is to retain gains achieved during this industry downturn. We are doing this across the globe. For example, in one region, we are taking advantage of the current downturn to negotiate with our main supplier, lock in lower rates through 2022 and upgrade with newer and more capable equipment. It not only improve our rates but is also expected to improve our reliability. As we look ahead in the supply chain, we see opportunities for more strategic supplier relationships and standardization. At the analyst meeting, we shared with you the cost savings achieved in the oilfield category. These reductions were achieved through standardization and supply rationalization where we went from having 35 suppliers in the past to 4 going forward. On Gorgon, we have worked to standardize and intend to replicate subsea equipment, generating procurement and installation efficiencies as well as considerable cost savings. And lastly, we've been working at standardizing the valves for some time, and we'll start deploying the standard valves on future projects.
Turning to Slide 12, let me give you some project updates. At Gorgon, we commenced LNG production on March 7. We ramped up total production to approximately 90,000 barrels per day, and we shipped the first cargo on March 21. Since late March, we have incurred downtime at the plant due to mechanical issues with the propane refrigerant circuit at Train 1. Repairs to this equipment are nearing completion, and we are in the process of reinstating the propane refrigerant circuit. We expect to restart Train 1 in the next few weeks and resume LNG production within the 30- to 60-day estimate we provided previously. We still expect to achieve Train 1 ramp-up within the previous guidance of 6 to 8 months from initial start-up. Construction on Trains 2 and 3 is progressing as planned, and we anticipate these trains being ready for start-up at roughly 6 months intervals.
Turning to Slide 13. At all 9 development wells are completed. We expect to release the drilling rig in the next few months following well cleanup activities. Offshore platform hookup and commissioning is progressing on track with this work expected to be complete well in advance of plant start-up. At the plant site, piping, electrical and instrumentation work is progressing well. Our plan reflects absorbed performance rates on other Australia LNG projects. Actual rates are currently on track with our plan, and the outlook for first LNG remains mid-2017. Train 2 construction work is also progressing on schedule. 12 of 24 process modules required for Train 2 startup are now on site, and module deliveries are meeting scheduled milestones.
Turning to Slide 14. I'd like to share a brief update on the other projects, which we are expecting to start up this year. At Angola LNG, gas has been introduced into the plant, and the team is working to the start-up process with dehydration ongoing ahead of commencing liquefaction. We expect LNG production eminently and anticipate shipping the next cargo in May. At hookup and commissioning is ongoing. All structures topsides and pipelines are installed, and the living quarters platform is now occupied, enabling increased manpower on piping, electrical and commissioning work. Batch drilling of the first 10 wells is complete, and first production is expected later this year. At Chuandongbei, Train 1 started up in January, and we were able to ramp up to full capacity within 30 days. Train 2 came online in early April, and ramp-up is in progress. We expect to start Train 3 this quarter. At Alder, topside has been installed, and subsea installation work is progressing. At well completions are currently ongoing. First production is expected from both these projects later this year.
Pat will now share an update of our asset sales program.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Joe. Turning to Slide 15. Asset sales are routine part of our business. They generate needed cash, and they enable a more strategic, effective and capital-efficient portfolio. Over the next 2 years, we are targeting $5 billion to $10 bi
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Joe. Turning to Slide 15. Asset sales are routine part of our business. They generate needed cash, and they enable a more strategic, effective and capital-efficient portfolio. Over the next 2 years, we are targeting $5 billion to $10 billion in sales proceeds. The assets targeted for sale are marketable, and we believe the prospective transactions are executable as well. We generally do not discuss specific assets targeted for sale until we have a transaction. However, there has been growing media coverage since our Analyst Day on a few of these prospective sales and as such, we wanted to provide updates where possible. 
The chart highlights some specific transactions that are in the public domain. You will note the vast majority of these are not oil price-sensitive and thus, we expect to be able to obtain good value on the sale. There were no significant transactions in the first quarter, but activity had picked up in the second quarter. Already known second quarter transactions include the sale of our interest in 2 gas storage facilities in Western Canada, the sale of our KLM pipeline in Western San Joaquin crude oil pipelines in California and the divestiture of 19 sales and associated assets located primarily in the Gulf of Mexico Alder shall and in Louisiana State waters.
In 2015, we signed an agreement to sell our New Zealand downstream operations subject to certain regulatory approval. Those regulatory approvals were received yesterday, and we now anticipate final closing mid-year.
Just last week, we reached an agreement to sell our assets in Hawaii. The sale includes a 58,000-barrel per day refinery, interest in a 58-site branded service station network, 4 product distribution terminals, pipeline systems and other downstream-related assets. This transaction is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to be completed in the second half of 2016.
In addition, we are soliciting interest to sell our 75% shareholding in South Africa downstream. We are also exploring potential interest in our geothermal business and Myanmar upstream assets. In aggregate, while it's always difficult to be precise about specific timing, we currently have line of sight on around $2 billion in proceeds, maybe a little higher for 2016. And because we have multiple transactions in the queue, including those not highlighted on the slide, we have confidence in achieving our 2-year $5 billion to $10 billion target.
Turning to Slide 16, I'd like to close with another slide from our recent investor session. It's an illustration of how we get cash balance next year. In this slide, we used $52 Brent as it was the actual average price in 2015 and in line with averages sell side analyst price targets for 2017. However, we are committed to balancing at any reasonable price. Spending will come down significantly this year and next as major development projects get finished and come online as we high grade future investments to shorter-cycle higher-return opportunity and as we get more efficient and lower our cost structure. Cash generation will grow, not only because of production but also because of accretive cash margins on the new production. We'll continue to streamline the portfolio. In short, we are taking the steps necessary to compete in the lower price environment. If a lower price environment persists for longer, we will adjust and pursue even more significant cost savings and even greater cuts in capital to continue to lower our cash flow breakeven. We intend to be a resilient competitor regardless of the price environment.
Okay. That concludes our prepared remarks. And we're now ready to take some questions. [Operator Instructions] Jonathan, please open the lines for questions.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just Pat, I want to start off on dividend growth. Just your thoughts on raising the dividend in 2016. Is that still a priority for the company and then how we should think about timing?
componenttext: So just Pat, I want to start off on dividend growth. Just your thoughts on raising the dividend in 2016. Is that still a priority for the company and then how we should think about timing?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. Sustaining and growing the dividend is still the first priority from a cash use standpoint for the corporation. It long has been and continues to be. Obviously, our immediate financial environment makes this challenging. We have long said that
componenttext: Sure. Yes. Sustaining and growing the dividend is still the first priority from a cash use standpoint for the corporation. It long has been and continues to be. Obviously, our immediate financial environment makes this challenging. We have long said that we'll raise the dividend when our cash flow and our earnings allow it to be sustained. And obviously, in first quarter, that was not the circumstances that we found ourselves in and, therefore, a deferral was prudent. I think going forward, the timing will obviously be dependent upon future cash, future earnings, what happens to price, what happens to our project ramp-up, how all that plays out in future quarters. We'll also have to take a look at that we think is happening to commodity prices over a longer sweep of time because, again, we're looking at a dividend being essentially a commitment in perpetuity. We're very aware of our 28-year record of consecutive annual per share payment increases, and that will be taken into account. So the board will take all this into account as it looks at dividends each and every quarter.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: When I look at the composition of the upstream earnings, it seems like the U.S. screams lackluster compared to the international component. And to me, that's a proxy for short cycle versus long cycle. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about h
componenttext: When I look at the composition of the upstream earnings, it seems like the U.S. screams lackluster compared to the international component. And to me, that's a proxy for short cycle versus long cycle. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how you envision the economics there changing for short cycle, maybe improving relative to long cycle longer term?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, let me start by saying that prices were very low in the first quarter. As Pat mentioned, there were more a number of onetime events in the first quarter, which adversely impacted our production. Going forward, we still expect to realize the gr
componenttext: Okay. Well, let me start by saying that prices were very low in the first quarter. As Pat mentioned, there were more a number of onetime events in the first quarter, which adversely impacted our production. Going forward, we still expect to realize the growth range we provided at our analyst meeting. The key for us is to really exercise the things within our control, and that is to continue to drive cost down and to improve our efficiencies. And we have given several proof points in the past about how much progress we've done in that regard. We're now in full horizontal factory mode in the Permian. We brought our well cost down by about 40%, and we have about 4,000 well locations that offer us a 10% rate of return at around $50 WTI. And when you add on top of all of that the royalty advances that have, we see our activity in the Permian as being very, very strong. So the key for us is to continue to be competitive, and we do that very well because we also have a JV, so we have a good line of sight on how well other people are operating in the basin. And of course, we screen them based on our own economics and lastly, the royalty advantage give us a tremendous boost here.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just like to add to that, as we lower our operating expenses from a corporate standpoint as well as in terms of organizational efficiencies, you're going to continue to see those benefits come through as well. And I talked earlier about transitional
componenttext: And I just like to add to that, as we lower our operating expenses from a corporate standpoint as well as in terms of organizational efficiencies, you're going to continue to see those benefits come through as well. And I talked earlier about transitional costs, severance costs being one of those that I would highlight, that impacted the U.S. segment in this particular quarter. And as we move through that, we'll obviously have stronger earnings once those are concluded.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: To support that, our cost at the center has gone down by 20%, and many SKUs, in our upstream in particular, have gone through tremendous reorganizational changes, and we're going to see the fruit of that over the next few quarters.
componenttext: To support that, our cost at the center has gone down by 20%, and many SKUs, in our upstream in particular, have gone through tremendous reorganizational changes, and we're going to see the fruit of that over the next few quarters.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You provided on Slide 16 an illustration of how you can get back to flat with a $52 assumption and an arrow pointing up with some price recovery. If that arrow is pointing downwards and you mentioned you'd prioritize the dividend and go into further cost
componenttext: You provided on Slide 16 an illustration of how you can get back to flat with a $52 assumption and an arrow pointing up with some price recovery. If that arrow is pointing downwards and you mentioned you'd prioritize the dividend and go into further cost savings and further capital -- CapEx cuts, how low could you go on CapEx? Can you give us an idea of what would be absolutely base number is for you guys?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Paul, I don't want to go into an absolute beast number. We've given you a range of $17 billion to $22 billion, and that range really well -- I think the $17 billion number was low, kind of, given a representative, a reasonable set of price expect
componenttext: I think, Paul, I don't want to go into an absolute beast number. We've given you a range of $17 billion to $22 billion, and that range really well -- I think the $17 billion number was low, kind of, given a representative, a reasonable set of price expectations. But frankly, if we find ourselves in a different place, affordability is a paramount consideration here for us, and we will continue to prioritize and high grade our opportunities. Our primary methodology in terms of capital allocation starts from what do we absolutely need to do to maintain reliability, maintain the asset integrity. And after that, after we have kind of concluded what that is for the operations, then we build up our capital program after that, and we have a great deal of flexibility. So each and every one of those layers of additional spend will have significant hurdles that they have to overcome, and affordability becomes an overriding consideration. So we'll continue to manage capital down commensurate with the price environment. We'll continue to push forward with our asset sales. I mentioned only 2 billion or so line of sight, maybe a little bit more for this year, but we see our way clear to the 5 billion to 10 billion program. And obviously for us to have confidence in saying it's 5 billion to 10 billion, we've got more lined up because we know not every transaction will be executed in the time frame that we've outlined. So we feel confident about our ability to get cash balance at any reasonable price here.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a key message from the Analyst Day was, obviously, as you get these big projects lined up, shift to shorter cycle shale but also monetize the large brownfield opportunity, which you already have behind existing facilities that you built, you should be
componenttext: So a key message from the Analyst Day was, obviously, as you get these big projects lined up, shift to shorter cycle shale but also monetize the large brownfield opportunity, which you already have behind existing facilities that you built, you should be much more capital intensive. That's a good thing. On the other hand, your debt burden is clearly going to be much higher, depends how long the down cycle lasts. So can you talk a little bit about where you want to end up in terms of debt burden. It's good news is you talk about extra disposal kind of fits over above the $5 billion to $10 billion, but talk to how you're going to get that down to a more useful level.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way I look at this and the way we look at it is, obviously, when you're in the peak of a price cycle that's when you want to have your restart balance sheet, have an ultraconservative balance sheet and that allows you to come through a price downturn.
componenttext: The way I look at this and the way we look at it is, obviously, when you're in the peak of a price cycle that's when you want to have your restart balance sheet, have an ultraconservative balance sheet and that allows you to come through a price downturn. Right now, we're sitting at a 22% debt ratio. We showed a slide at the Security Analyst Meeting that said we could take summer between $25 billion to $30 billion of incremental debt, and that would take us up to about a 30% debt ratio. There's nothing necessarily magic about the 30%. It was just an indicative place to do a measurement versus ourselves versus peers. But I would see as you go through the lows of a price cycle, you would expect your debt burden to increase into the 30%-ish range, maybe a little bit higher on a temporary basis but if you look through the whole cycle I think a good place for the company like Chevron with projects that we take on, our size our scale our scope would be probably in the low 20s through the cycle, but getting into the 30%-ish range, we could handle that if it's temporary.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the restructuring the cash is there anything else we should focus is it more in line with the EBIT that you would have expected?
componenttext: And then the restructuring the cash is there anything else we should focus is it more in line with the EBIT that you would have expected?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say cash from operations was low this quarter operationally I would because accrued price but we did have the working capital consumption of about $1 billion, and then there were several items that were not particularly ratable. Pension contr
componenttext: Yes, I would say cash from operations was low this quarter operationally I would because accrued price but we did have the working capital consumption of about $1 billion, and then there were several items that were not particularly ratable. Pension contributions were one of those. Affiliate dividends weren't particularly ratable as well.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess it's kind of a follow-up to that question because the question comes from a multiple industry right now is when do you start re-upping spending in contrast to when do how far do you repair your balance sheet. But obviously, with companies of your
componenttext: I guess it's kind of a follow-up to that question because the question comes from a multiple industry right now is when do you start re-upping spending in contrast to when do how far do you repair your balance sheet. But obviously, with companies of your size, the issue is long-cycle capital projects and light of your recent comments is there balance sheet getting up into the 30s, should we think about utilizing kind of harvest mode until you get that balance sheet back to where you want it to be. And I wonder can you just kind of characterize for us what your appetite is for large-scale you project sanctions and top of my mind is Tengiz.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just go back to our cash flow priorities: dividend is #1, investing in the business is #2 and then prudent financial structure strong balance sheet is #3. By virtue of the opportunities we have ahead of us in terms of moving towards more short cycle,
componenttext: I'll just go back to our cash flow priorities: dividend is #1, investing in the business is #2 and then prudent financial structure strong balance sheet is #3. By virtue of the opportunities we have ahead of us in terms of moving towards more short cycle, frankly all of the advantages we have in the Permian, and we have growing capital flexibility. So we will see shorter-cycle movement of there that obviously puts less of a strain in your balance sheet because you can adjust those as conditions permit. What we aren't going to continue to go far did major capital projects and SGP is the poster child for that. That's an important project for us in an economic budget for us to go forward with, and we will continue to do though. So I think of it as being, over time, a better balance between short cycle opportunities and low cycle opportunities. We're coming off a period that was significantly weighted by long-duration, highly capital-intensive projects and w3 moving the portfolio now, our investments now to a better balance between of those. So I think we've got tremendous amount of flexibility to not only reinvest in the business in short cycle, take on selective high-graded wonderful projects like FTP but also then have opportunity to restore the balance sheet. Those balancing activities -- I mean, that will all be part of our balancing considerations as you go forward.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: There are no debt targets as such then?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know there's been an increased focus on project execution and emphasized on the third quarter call from John and the Analyst Day, more engineering, less reliance on the third parties and more oversight. Maybe, Joe, on the call today how do you how do th
componenttext: I know there's been an increased focus on project execution and emphasized on the third quarter call from John and the Analyst Day, more engineering, less reliance on the third parties and more oversight. Maybe, Joe, on the call today how do you how do these plans increase your confidence and ability to improve execution as you deliver this broader slate of projects and where are the biggest areas for continued improvement or execution risk as you bring them online?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start by acknowledging that we do some things well. We have delivered good project. We have Jack/St. Malo. We have the Bibiyana expansion. We have the These are 3 recent examples where we actually delivered on cost and schedule. Having said that, we
componenttext: I'll start by acknowledging that we do some things well. We have delivered good project. We have Jack/St. Malo. We have the Bibiyana expansion. We have the These are 3 recent examples where we actually delivered on cost and schedule. Having said that, we and the industry have learned a great deal over the last few years, and the only thing we can do is to actually take those learnings and apply them on future projects. Gorgon Train 2 and 3 and Wheatstone Trains 1 and 2 will benefit from all the learnings on Angola LNG and Gorgon Train 1. All the things the initiatives highlighted at the analyst meeting in terms of what it takes to actually improve our chances of execution we are committed to doing those we're moving a lot of things in-house, we're going to focus on design and engineering are going to assure those the signs were going to pick the right contractors are going to work hard on the right contracting strategy we need to get projects ready for execution, and we're applying all of those on FGP and recall the slide that we had back in March. SGP is going to be wonderful for us because this is countercyclical. We're going to go into a period reduce capacity and in the industry were going to go into a period where we will have the right organization capability working on those projects. And I think it's a tremendous time for us to actually deliver better on those projects. We will have lower execution risk as well on the base shale and tight. We've done load-backs on some other short-term investments, and we don't talk about it that much, but we actually beat the expectations always as you move into short cycle we're very confident delivering those as you take the learnings on the MCPs, whether it's NGP or other project doing, I believe our chances of improving execution and delivering those projects should be improved.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Joe, just curious. I think a lot of people sort of comment, especially in the U.S. shale, there's a high cost deflation maybe coming to pretty close to a bottom. So I don't know whether you agree. And I also want to see if you do. It does make sense now that starts to in the supply cost curve given that it may be close to a bottom and how far you guys want to do that. How far you may be willing to do it.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I agree with you. I think our opportunity is to work with suppliers and to see if we can have an arrangement that actually give us a better shot at costs, and we're already having those conversations with our suppliers. Now key to this is how much capital
componenttext: I agree with you. I think our opportunity is to work with suppliers and to see if we can have an arrangement that actually give us a better shot at costs, and we're already having those conversations with our suppliers. Now key to this is how much capital going to put into those activities. And as Pat said, we have to consider all the lenses before we commit capital our intention is to move in that directions. I believe we have the organizational capability to deliver on this, and the conversation we're having with our suppliers tell us we can do so. And those conversation with respect to locking in rigs and material give us greater confidence that we can sustain some of the savings and the efficiencies that we're seeing right now. So we're exactly working on the kind of things you're suggesting.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you comment in terms of that would kind of expense you are willing to do, say, in your 50% [ph] of your supply requirement for the next 5 year or lock in for 3-year, 5-year any kind of the magnitude that you can you can share?
componenttext: So can you comment in terms of that would kind of expense you are willing to do, say, in your 50% [ph] of your supply requirement for the next 5 year or lock in for 3-year, 5-year any kind of the magnitude that you can you can share?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All I can tell you is it takes also the supplier to be willing to have those conversations. We clearly have talked about 1 year, 2-year, potentially 3 years in certain areas on rigs, and we're willing to consider that. But like I said, it got to depend on
componenttext: All I can tell you is it takes also the supplier to be willing to have those conversations. We clearly have talked about 1 year, 2-year, potentially 3 years in certain areas on rigs, and we're willing to consider that. But like I said, it got to depend on the program that we have, the pace in which we want to invest, but all of those are on the table. And I think the suppliers are increasingly willing to have that discussion with us. And they're going to see us with the position that I've described earlier in the Permian as a key customer for them. They're going to view those relationships more strategic, they're going to be willing to work with us everything in the contract. It's not just the way that it's important as a lot of other clauses in the contracts and portable, so they will see us as a reliable customer with a commitment to the region, and they clearly want to do business with us.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the asset sales commentary. You talked about $2 billion or so for this year. And so it kind of back-end loads the high end of the 5 to 10 target. So maybe any additional color you have an whether the oil price environment or the asset
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the asset sales commentary. You talked about $2 billion or so for this year. And so it kind of back-end loads the high end of the 5 to 10 target. So maybe any additional color you have an whether the oil price environment or the asset sale environment in any way kind of pushes you towards the low end or high end of that range? How are you think about it now?

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think what we're seeing is it's acknowledgment that some of these transactions take much longer to close for regulatory approval reasons or whatnot than you might think. And so we're just being cautious in terms of the guidance that we're giving, no
componenttext: No, I think what we're seeing is it's acknowledgment that some of these transactions take much longer to close for regulatory approval reasons or whatnot than you might think. And so we're just being cautious in terms of the guidance that we're giving, not only in terms of the 5 to 10. We feel that is executable. Those transactable, but pinning it down to whether it's going to happen in the next 9 months is very hard for us to say at this point. We have a number of transaction activities underway, and getting the precise timing as to whether it closes in 2016 or it closes in 2017 is where the difficult challenge lies. They can be very lumpy. I do agree its back-end loaded for this year, we believe, but I think it's also likely to be back-end loaded for the 2016 to 2017 time period. Overall, we still have confidence in that $5 billion to $10 billion range that we've indicated for the 2 years.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Understood. How much is locked in for 2Q, by the way?

componenttext: I won't give a number completely for 2Q. I'll just say, again, for line of sight for this year, we anticipate somewhere around 2, maybe a little bit more $1 billion. So won't to get precise for the quarter. I feel good about April because it's almost closed, but I don't want to have any more precise than that.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Terreson from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Terreson from Evercore ISI.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Today's commentary seems to emphasize that cost productivity and asset sales and performance from new projects is going to lead to stronger cash flow for Chevron, and it seems pretty reasonable to me. And on this point, I have 2 questions. First, for clar
componenttext: Today's commentary seems to emphasize that cost productivity and asset sales and performance from new projects is going to lead to stronger cash flow for Chevron, and it seems pretty reasonable to me. And on this point, I have 2 questions. First, for clarification, does the divestiture under consideration in Myanmar represent the majority of the position in that country? And the second question is somewhat different, if the industry does recover and free cash flow does materialize, the question is whether they're likely to be changes to Chevron's capital priorities over the medium term? And I ask this question I think pad talk a few minutes about greater focus on returns being likely the future, but I don't think much was said about how share repurchases might plan to so just wanted to see if can get some color on the capital management priority now we change over the medium term, if they do it all.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't really see our priorities changing over the medium term. We're consistent in how we use the cash and the priorities we have for that. We laid out the investment program, not only for the rest of this year, but for 2017, 2018 where the shift is the
componenttext: I don't really see our priorities changing over the medium term. We're consistent in how we use the cash and the priorities we have for that. We laid out the investment program, not only for the rest of this year, but for 2017, 2018 where the shift is the short-term cycle investments. We'll be selective major capital projects that get pushed into the portfolio pushed into the queue. FTP is, obviously, the headliner on it that. I don't see share repurchases coming into play in the medium term here. That is the last use of cash, and I don't see us being in a position where that would be a relevant item for us in the medium term. In terms of Myanmar, it is a full exit.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I mean, our objective is to get balance in 2017. And obviously, if we're falling short on asset sales proceeds for a reason or other, we would want to take that into account in determining what the capital outlays are because it really is the obj
componenttext: Okay. So I mean, our objective is to get balance in 2017. And obviously, if we're falling short on asset sales proceeds for a reason or other, we would want to take that into account in determining what the capital outlays are because it really is the objective to get balance. So there would be a trade-off potentially there if we weren't seeing the execution on asset sales. We don't anticipate that being the case, however. In terms of the prioritization though, let me just go back to the logic and the process that we have for building up the capital program. We start with the integrity and reliability foundation and in each and every layer of projects above that competes on its merit on a returns focus kind of basis and we will balance the short cycle investment and we will balance initiation and commitment to larger, longer-cycle capital projects. Again, the only one that upsized kind of queued up here and the near term would be future growth projects. So we will take all of that into account, the overlying -- overarching objective though is to get balanced on cash in 2017. And we continue to be very focused on capital discipline, and so there will be high hurdle rates for all of the products coming forward for possible inclusion in the capital budget.

componenttextpreview: Just a question looking at some of the pre-FID projects. I was wondering if you could give an idea of where the oil price breakeven has come down to for some of these key projects such as the complex, some of your discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico and als
componenttext: Just a question looking at some of the pre-FID projects. I was wondering if you could give an idea of where the oil price breakeven has come down to for some of these key projects such as the complex, some of your discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico and also raise back in the U.K. And the second question was just looking at returns. I'm just wondering if you look at things internationally, does anything come even close on a risk-adjusted basis to the Permian when you take into account ideological, fiscal, political risk? Just wondering how you look at that capital allocation.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the deepwater question first. Just to put in context, we're already producing about 140,000 barrels a day in the Gulf of Mexico in the deepwater. And we do that through 5 operated assets and 4 non-operated assets. We're also the largest leasehol
componenttext: I'll take the deepwater question first. Just to put in context, we're already producing about 140,000 barrels a day in the Gulf of Mexico in the deepwater. And we do that through 5 operated assets and 4 non-operated assets. We're also the largest leaseholder in the Gulf. So in the near term with that footprint, we do see many brownfield Deepwater opportunities. In fact, 80% of our spend, in development spend over the next few years is going to be geared towards brownfield development, such as Jack/St. Malo and Tahiti, where we actually have good economics. We've already said the single low breakeven is in the $20 to $40 Brent range. We also demonstrated tremendous improvement in drilling and completion efficiency, so we continue to bring the cost equation down. Now if are talking about new greenfield development, we got few things that need to happen there. Obviously, we need scale and the resource, but we also need to rethink about how we bring our development. We talked before about optimizing our development concept where we could be trading lower plateau and maybe NPV for greater capital efficiencies. And this is another place where we actually need our suppliers. We need to work closely with them to continue to drive the cost down. This is an important area for us to be good at, and we're committed to do that. Now in terms of how does the Permian compete, we just can't be a a Permian company. We have a lot of other places we actually have good resources. We talked about Tengiz, we talked about we talked about Indonesia. Australia is going to give us those opportunities allowed the Permian gives us tremendous advantage the size of our company will require us to actually be broader and to put our capital in places where we can get good economics but not to be solely 1 asset class company.

headline: Chevron Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with Wheatstone, we're still operating under the same funding appropriation, which we have communicated to you previously. We do acknowledge we're seeing cost pressures, but at the same time, these have been offset by favorable foreign exchange
componenttext: I'll start with Wheatstone, we're still operating under the same funding appropriation, which we have communicated to you previously. We do acknowledge we're seeing cost pressures, but at the same time, these have been offset by favorable foreign exchange were working very hard to mitigate of those cost pressures earlier this year -- earlier this week, we have a good review of the project, and we're very encouraged by the progress. I alluded to that in my prepared remarks. So the progress you make over the next 8 to 12 months will be very important in terms of where we're going to end up. But for now, there is really no reason to change our view on the cost. And again, Wheatstone is a huge resource base for us and it's very important to deliver it. Now in terms of Gorgon, we've seen cost pressures in Gorgon but at the moment, really, we're not going to change the cross estimate that we have provided previously.
